I regret the role I played in causing such pain, and I remain committed to fighting for LGBTQ+ equality. You can learn more about my legislative record here: https://t.co/EDmF7KuMvY

I‚Äôm so grateful to my friends and loved ones, both gay and straight, who patiently helped me see how my past positions on these issues were at odds with my values, my aloha, and that they were causing people harm.
When we divide people based on who they are or who they love, all we are doing is adding fuel to the flames that perpetuate bigotry and hatred.

When we deny LGBTQ+ people the basic rights that exist for every American, we are denying their humanity - denying that they are equal. We are also creating a dangerous environment that breeds discrimination and violence.
I look forward to being able to share more of my story and experiences growing up ‚Äì not as an excuse, but in the hopes that it may inspire others to truly live aloha; to love and care for others.

But over the years, I formed my own opinions based on my life experience that changed my views ‚Äì at a personal level in having aloha, love, for all people, and ensuring that every American, regardless of sexual orientation or gender identity, is treated equally under the law.

While many Americans may relate to growing up in a conservative home, my story is a little different because my father was very outspoken. He was an activist who was fighting against gay rights and marriage equality in Hawaii ‚Äì and at that time, I forcefully defended him.

But I also grew up in a socially conservative household, where I was raised to believe that marriage should only be between a man and a woman. For a period of my life I didn‚Äôt see the contradiction in those beliefs.
I grew up knowing that every person is a child of God, and equally loved by God. I have always believed in the fundamental rights and equality of all people.

That cannot happen, because every single American deserves to be treated equally ‚Äì by their fellow Americans and under the law. I will continue to fight for LGBTQ+ people, whether they‚Äôre in school or serving in uniform, trying to get healthcare, or taking care of their family.

I know that LGBTQ+ people still struggle, are still facing discrimination, are still facing abuse and still fear that their hard-won rights are going to be taken away by people who hold views like I used to.
My views have changed significantly since then, and my record in Congress over the last 6 years reflects what is in my heart: A strong and ongoing commitment to fighting for LGBTQ+ rights.
Many years ago, I apologized for my words and, more importantly, for the negative impact that they had. I sincerely repeat my apology today.

Aloha. In my past, I said and believed things that were wrong, and worse, hurtful to people in the LGBTQ+ community and their loved ones. I‚Äôm deeply sorry for having said and believed them. https://t.co/BWlOBk9ZnN

Real change requires people coming together and taking action. #FIRSTSTEPAct will come before Congress tomorrow, with bipartisan support. But some are putting politics before the well-being of people, and opposing this. Urge Congress to vote YES for #prisonreform tomorrow.

Prisons are overcrowded, and they‚Äôre costing Americans big time -- America pays more than $80 billion a year to be exact. #FIRSTSTEPAct ensures pre-release halfway houses or home confinement is available and gives people tools to reenter society & end cycle of recidivism.
The #FIRSTSTEPAct makes sure that prisoners are treated, assessed, and rehabilitated with policies that are based on evidence, not personal or institutional bias.

The #FIRSTSTEPAct uses evidence-based approaches that have already been proven to help states like Texas, Alabama and Alaska reduce crime, keep families together, and shrink prison populations, reducing cost to taxpayers.

Formerly incarcerated people face huge legal obstacles to finding employment and housing after release. Rejoining society is often too difficult, leading to many ending up back behind bars. This leaves broken families in its wake. We need #prisonreform now.

One piece of legislation won‚Äôt fix every problem in our #criminaljustice system. The #FIRSTSTEPAct is the common ground that exists today where we can get something good done now that will have a direct effect on people‚Äôs lives, while we continue to work toward #prisonreform.

Too many people get stuck in our broken criminal justice system and never make it out. We can‚Äôt take an all or nothing approach to reform while so many people and families suffer under the status quo. The #FIRSTSTEPAct is the first step towards comprehensive #prisonreform.
According to the National Institute of Justice, three out of every four people who spend time in prison will be rearrested within five years. The #FIRSTSTEPAct can begin to change this. #prisonreform

In hyper-partisan Washington, passing bipartisan legislation is rare. But one thing that has brought Ds and Rs together is the need to fix our criminal justice system. Tomorrow we can begin to do that by passing the #FIRSTSTEPAct in the House. #prisonreform
We still need sentencing reform, but we can‚Äôt take an all-or-nothing approach on #prisonreform. We need to focus on the changes we can make today, and the #FIRSTSTEPAct is one of those changes.

We can no longer afford to maintain the conditions of a broken system. We spend more than $80 billion a year locking up 2.3 million people‚Äîmore than any country on earth. I support the #FIRSTSTEPAct and ask you to stand with me for real positive change.
